misc.text: ğŸ§¡Lost in Translation: For this chapter title, Oda deliberately chose wording that sounds like a line from a fairy tale, fitting for the Elbaf arc, which makes it difficult to translate. If it were up to me, I'd render it like this: ğŸ—ï¸The very strongest thing in all the world. misc.title: #ONEPIECE1174 Well, the only kanji in the WSJ title version is â€œ1ç•ªâ€ (ichiban â€“ â€œnumber oneâ€), and now the official version says itâ€™s supposed to be written in pure hiraganaâ€”â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“.â€ This makes it much
misc.text: #ONEPIECE1174 Well, the only kanji in the WSJ title version is â€œ1ç•ªâ€ (ichiban â€“ â€œnumber oneâ€), and now the official version says itâ€™s supposed to be written in pure hiraganaâ€”â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“.â€ This makes it much simpler, as if it were written from a childâ€™s perspective. In my initial explanation, I focused on the â€œmonoâ€ (ã‚‚ã®) part of the chapter title because it was written in hiragana instead of kanji. In Japanese, â€œmonoâ€ can be written using two different kanji: â€œç‰©â€ (for non-living things) and â€œè€…â€ (for a person). I think it was intended that way to make the meaning ambiguous (and I still think it is, in my opinion)â€”whether it refers to parental love as the â€œstrongest thing,â€ or to "the strongest person/s,â€ referring to the epic panel shown at the end of the chapter. However, when referring to the â€œstrongest person,â€ the usual descriptive term would be written in kanji as â€œæœ€å¼·â€ (saikyÅ), rather than in hiragana as â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“ã¤ã‚ˆã„â€ (ichiban tsuyoi). In summary, there is still no official confirmation of what the â€œstrongestâ€ refers to in this chapter, but the simplified hiragana in the chapter title makes it feel as if it were written by a child. The children witnessed both their parentsâ€™/relativesâ€™/teacher's strong and unconditional love for themâ€”and they also saw how they were saved by Luffy and Loki at the end in their strongest forms. So personally, I think the title remains open to both interpretations. misc.text: Wakana Yamazaki (Ran in Detective Conan) is taking a break due to health issues, and Akemi Okamura will step in as her substitute. The two voiced Nojiko and Nami in ONE PIECE. Years ago, Yamazaki covered for Okamura during maternity leave; now the roles are reversed.ğŸ€

items.text: #ONEPIECE1174 Well, the only kanji in the WSJ title version is â€œ1ç•ªâ€ (ichiban â€“ â€œnumber oneâ€), and now the official version says itâ€™s supposed to be written in pure hiraganaâ€”â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“.â€ This makes it much simpler, as if it were written from a childâ€™s perspective. In my initial explanation, I focused on the â€œmonoâ€ (ã‚‚ã®) part of the chapter title because it was written in hiragana instead of kanji. In Japanese, â€œmonoâ€ can be written using two different kanji: â€œç‰©â€ (for non-living things) and â€œè€…â€ (for a person). I think it was intended that way to make the meaning ambiguous (and I still think it is, in my opinion)â€”whether it refers to parental love as the â€œstrongest thing,â€ or to "the strongest person/s,â€ referring to the epic panel shown at the end of the chapter. However, when referring to the â€œstrongest person,â€ the usual descriptive term would be written in kanji as â€œæœ€å¼·â€ (saikyÅ), rather than in hiragana as â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“ã¤ã‚ˆã„â€ (ichiban tsuyoi). In summary, there is still no official confirmation of what the â€œstrongestâ€ refers to in this chapter, but the simplified hiragana in the chapter title makes it feel as if it were written by a child. The children witnessed both their parentsâ€™/relativesâ€™/teacher's strong and unconditional love for themâ€”and they also saw how they were saved by Luffy and Loki at the end in their strongest forms. So personally, I think the title remains open to both interpretations. ONE PIECE ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒƒãƒ•ã€å…¬å¼ã€‘/ Official (@Eiichiro_Staff) ã€è¨‚æ­£ã€‘ æœ¬æ—¥ç™ºå£²ã®é€±åˆŠå°‘å¹´ã‚¸ãƒ£ãƒ³ãƒ—12å·ã«æ²è¼‰ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹1174è©±ã®ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«ã«ã€ç·¨é›†éƒ¨ã®ãƒŸã‚¹ã«ã‚ˆã‚Šèª¤è¡¨è¨˜ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ èª¤)ã€ã›ã‹ã„ã§1ç•ªã¤ã‚ˆã„ã‚‚ã®ã€Ÿ æ­£)ã€ã›ã‹ã„ã§1ã°ã‚“ã¤ã‚ˆã„ã‚‚ã®ã€Ÿ ãŠè©«ã³ã—ã¦è¨‚æ­£ã„ãŸã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ #ONEPIECE #ä»Šé€±ã®ãƒ¯ãƒ³ãƒ” â€” https://nitter.net/Eiichiro_Staff/status/2023049675188957330#m

items.text: Wakana Yamazaki (Ran in Detective Conan) is taking a break due to health issues, and Akemi Okamura will step in as her substitute. The two voiced Nojiko and Nami in ONE PIECE. Years ago, Yamazaki covered for Okamura during maternity leave; now the roles are reversed.ğŸ€
